comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice photo. Before I was born & not being Irish- I also don't know what the Hell they were doing, but it seems that it interested many people back then - - -

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Barton was the name of Erskine Childers mother and they were part of the Barton and Guestier wine growing and shipping company.  The original Barton was Thomas - is it possible that the two are related.  I tried to google the name but did not do too well.  It does appear that the Childers family had strong connections to Waterford.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Well, keep at it! ;) No T. Barton in Waterford in either 1901 or 1911 census...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Re Barton and Childers, see our OTHER Flickr photostream (that's swanky for you)!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20342758@N00
comment._content: It may be a red herring, but a "Bovril boat" was a boat used in London to carry sewage out to sea ([en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bovril_Boats]). The small boats in the foreground don't seem to match the description, but perhaps the larger ones in the background do.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/paul_appleyard] Oh, this is pure gold and would at least explain the Bovril, thank you!! However, just wondering if so many people would turn out to see, in effect, sewage ships... (maybe it was a slow news day in Waterford)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: The pontoon and access gangway in the photo were part of the ferry boat terminal. People were rowed across to the Ferrybank side of the river.One of the boats used is moored at the the pontoon.  The ferry operated up to at least the late 1950s although from another pontoon further up river in later times. I traveled in it with my father during that decade

comment.author: 78516474@N00
comment._content: I seem to remember in the early days of Telefís Eireann that there was a TV ad featuring a man rowing a jar of Bovril. It can also be found here: collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O75968/poster-bovril-prevents-... - maybe it has some old advertising connection?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/carrignafoy] Well, there's definitely a Bovril connection with notices about the product (have added note on the picture), but this shot is just very bizarre. If you examine the tug(?) in the foreground, it looks as if the steps, upper structure and lamp post are all actually part of the boat...

P.S. That poster is gorgeous!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Not sure why but the man on the ferry pontoon has a stack of Bovril tins lashed to a pole. The tug is not actually a boat but an iron pontoon originally built at the Neptune shipyard.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Ah, I was seeing them as posters or notices. So you reckon they're a tower of Bovril tins?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I'm pretty certain they are large tins alright, but what the purpose was is another thing, I have a feeling the crowds were not there for him though, possibly a regatta at the boat club across the river. Antique Bovril Can

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] That is one giant tin, alright! And you're probably right - a regatta or similar - I was developing Bovil Tin myopia, and forgetting about the bigger picture (in both senses of the word).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] added a note about Timbertoes, the furthermost bridge on the horizon of this photo. There's some nice history here on this American oak bridge.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Andrew Carnegie laid the foundation for waterford library in oct 1903 still looking for the date He had been in dublin before this see this link for image www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/history-heritage/hist...

comment.author: 59057347@N00
comment._content: That's not a tug in the foreground - its a landing stage.
